summary: PEDV belongs to the genus of Alphacoronavirus, the family of Coronaviridae and the subfamily of Coronavirinae. it causes 80 to 100% fatality rate in suckling piglets. the outbreak of PED in the united states in 2013 caused significant economic loss. cytokine storm triggered by virus infection is characterized by a significant increase of proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-, IL-1, IL-8, and IL-6) that subsequently results in fever, edema, organ dysfunction and even death. PRRs also recognize endogenous molecules that are released during cellular injury or tissue damage. PEDV infection increased the expression of proinflammatory cytokines. HMGB1 acetylation and release were regulated by SIRT1, histone acetyltransferase and NF-B. further studies showed that the nucleoprotein of PEDV promoted acetylation and release of HMGB1. PEDV infection induces the increase of proinflammatory cytokines. the cells were collected at 0, 2, 6, 12, 24hpi. mRNA levels of HMGB1 were analyzed by qRT-PCR. infected cells were collected at 6h, 12h and 24hpi to analyze the protein levels of HMGB1 in the cytoplasm and nucleus extracts separately after nuclear and cytoplasmic fractionation. the results showed that HMGB1 was translocated from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and released into extracellular space. the infected cells were collected at 6h, 12h and 24hpi to analyze HMGB1 protein levels in the cytoplasm and nucleus extracts by western blotting. the translocation of HMGB1 in infected cells at 6 hpi was studied by IFA. acetylated HMGB1, total HMGB1 in the supernatant and PEDV-N in the cells were analyzed by western blot. western blot analyzed the virus titer in the supernatant after RES treatment. RES treatment decreased the acetylation/release of HMGB1 significantly. but its effect on the expression level of PEDV-N was only shown at higher concentrations (10 and 20mM) the virus titer was measured by the plaque formation assay respectively. UV-inactivated virus was able to enter the cells but did not replicate in the cells. UV-PEDV infection also induced the release of acetylation HMGB1 in MOI-dependent manner. mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines were analyzed by qRT-PCR. mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines were analyzed by qRT-PCR. qRT-PCR result suggested that the increase of mRNA level of PEDV-N was concomitant with an elevated mRNA level of HMGB1 (2 fold) in a time- and dose-dependent manner. western blotting analysis showed that the expression of PEDV-N indeed promoted the acetylation/release of HMGB1 in dose and time-dependent manner. inflammatory cytokines induced by PEDV-N overexpression were inhibited. the results strongly suggested that the released HMGB1 indeed induced proinflammatory cytokine production. PEDV-N is enriched in the HMGB1 promotor and C/EBP binding motif is responsible for HMGB1 transcription. the optimized sonication time in CHIP experiment was explored. B. Vero cells were infected with PEDV (MOI=0.1) for 24h. PCR analysis of ChIP samples showed HA-tagged PEDV-N protein enriched in HMGB1 gene. data represented relative firefly luciferase activity normalized to renilla luciferase activity. results represent means SD of triplicate determinations. mutant reporter gene plasmid was co-transfected with PCA-N. deletion of C/EBP-binding motif (mLuc2-C) resulted in 75% decrease in luciferase activity. vero cells were infected with PEDV for 24h. the cells were lysed with the lysis buffer containing DNAase and RNase A. co-immunoprecipitation experiment was performed with PEDV-N antibody. vero cells were first transfected with PCA-N for 24h. HMGB1 antibody could decrease upregulation of proinflammatory cytokine. blockage of HMGB1 inhibits PEDV infection. mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-) in infected cells treated with HMGB1 antibody were evaluated by qRT-PCR. siNC was used as the negative control. the cells were infected PEDV for 24h. PEDV infection induces the elevation of mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines. vero cells were infected with PEDV at 2h, 6h, 12h and 24h. mRNA levels of cytokine IL-1, IL-6 and IL-8 were elevated at 24hpi. we infected the cells and determined the protein level of HMGB1 in the supernatant at different time points. acetylated and total HMGB1 levels were increased from 1hpi to 8hpi, but decreased later in the supernatant. this could be explained by the slight change of mRNA level of HMGB1in the infected cells. PEDV infection caused the translocation of HMGB1 from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and release into extracellular space. the cells were also immunostained by PEDV-N antibody. GAR treatment reduced the acetylation/release of HMGB1 and PEDV infection in a dose-dependent manner. a similar inhibitory trend was observed in the plaque formation assay with the maximum reduction of 85.4% at the concentration of 5 M. the acetylated HMGB1 or total HMGB1 in the supernatant and PEDV-N in cells were analyzed by western blot. the virus titer in the supernatant after NIC treatment was measured by the plaque formation assay. the results represent the means SD of triplicate determinations. NF-B inhibitor (BAY 11-7082) treatment reduced acetylation of HMGB1. all the results confirmed that histone acetyltransferase, SIRT1 and NF-B were involved in the acetylation of HMGB1. PEDV-N promotes the acetylation/release of HMGB1. mRNA level of HMGB1 or PEDV-N was analyzed by western blot. mRNA level of HMGB1 or PEDV-N was analyzed by western blot. ines were analyzed by qRT-PCR. the results represent the means SD of triplicate determinations. RES, and BAY treatment decreased the acetylation/release of HMGB1 caused by PEDV-N overexpression. qRT-PCR assay indicated PEDV-N overexpression led to the increase of mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines. the results strongly suggested that the released HMGB1 indeed induced proinflammatory cytokine production. chromatin is a critical step in the ChIP experiment, because genomic DNA should be sheared uniformly and randomly. the ideal DNA fragment size after sonication was 200-1000 bp. d and PCA-N, together with renilla luciferase reporter gene plasmid pRL-TK, were used as the negative control. renilla luciferase reporter gene plasmids were co-transfected with each mutant gene or WT plasmid (pHLuc2). PEDV-N only increased the transcription of pHLuc2 (1264 to +83) and pHLuc1 carrying the full-length promoter region. the data strongly suggested that the promoter region from 1264 to 822 was vital for HMGB1 gene transcription. BP- CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein (C/EBP) regulates the transcription of a number of genes via protein-protein interaction. C/EBP- can physically interact with other C/EBP proteins, such as Fos and Jun [42] co-immunoprecipitation experiment reveals that PEDV nucleoprotein interacts with C/EBP-. A. Vero cells were infected with PEDV (MOI=0.1) for 24h. mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-) in infected cells were evaluated by qRT-PCR. mRNA levels of proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-) were measured by qRT-PCR. siRNA knockdown experiment was performed to confirm the effect of HMGB1 on PEDV infection. the knockdown efficiency of HMGB1 was about 73%. blockage of HMGB1 could attenuate PEDV infection and decrease expression of proinflammatory cytokines. HMGB1 expression is induced in mice on days 3-7 post infection. the HMGB1-specific antibody can reduce the levels of inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. but the virus titer is not affected by HMGB1 antibody treatment. HMGB1 acetylation and release could be attenuated by deacetylase Sirt1 activator and histone acetyltransferase inhibitor treatment. PEDV-N expression promoted HMGB1 transcription, which was associated with putative C/EBP binding motif in HMGB1 promotor region. extracellular HMGB1 treatment may initiate antiviral responses to block HCV infection. intracellular HMGB1 is important for HCV RNA replication. the opposite effects of HMGB1 have also been reported on HIV-1 virus. the cells were cultured in high-glucose DMEM supplemented with 2% newborn calf serum and 2.5 g/mL of trypsin for 3 days. the cells were frozen and thawed for 3 times, the media was centrifuged at 12,000g for 10 min at 4°C. antibodies against HMGB1 and -actin were purchased from cell signaling technology (Danvers, CA) PEDV-N gene was first amplified using PCR with specific primers. the PCR product was digested with NotI and XbaI and ligated to pCAGGS-HA vector previously digested with these enzymes. HMGB1 promoter fragments were digested with KpnI and BglII. the cells in 6-well plates (Corning) were washed with ice-cold. the cells in 6-well plates were washed with ice-cold. the cells were lysed with the lysis buffer (50mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 150mM NaCl, 1% Triton X-100, 2mM EDTA, 0.1% SDS, 5mM sodium orthovanadate) the lysates were centrifuged at 12,000g for 30 min at 4°C. quantitative real-time PCR was performed using SYBR Green Master Mix. primer sequences for IL-1, IL-6, IL-8, TNF-, ORF3 of PEDV and GADPH are listed in Table 1. the cells were fixed with 4% formaldehyde for 15 min at room temperature. permeabilized with 0.1% Triton X-100 for 10 min and incubated with 5% BSA for 1h. the cells were incubated with either C/EBP- or NF-B antibody for 2h at 37°C. 1106 cells were cross-linked with 1% formaldehyde for 10 min at room temperature. reaction was quenched and washed with PBS for three times. cells were lysed with warm SDS lysis buffer for 10 min on ice. luciferase activity was determined with a dual-luciferase assay system. data represented relative firefly luciferase activity normalized to renilla luciferase activity. the medium was replaced with fresh DMEM supplemented with 2% newborn calf serum containing inhibitors. the plates were incubated for up to 24 h. the cytotoxicity experiment showed that resveratrol, nicotinamide, garcinol and BAY 11-7082 did not cause significant cytotoxicity at the working concentrations. histone acetyltransferase inhibitor Garcinol (GAR), SIRT1 activator Resveratrol (RES), SIRT1 inhibitor Nicotinamide (NIC) and NF-B inhibitor BAY 11-7082 (BAY) were obtained from Santa Cruz (Santa Cruz, CA) antibodies against HMGB1 and -actin were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (Danvers, MA) mutant luciferase reporter gene plasmids carrying mutations in transcription factor binding sites. mutant luciferase reporter gene plasmids were prepared with Mut Express® II Fast Mutagenesis kit. fidelity of the DNA constructs was verified by DNA sequencing. lysates were centrifuged at 12,000g for 30 min at 4°C. the proteins in the gel were transferred to polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) membranes were blocked with 3% BSA in PBS-T. the membranes were washed three times with PBS-T before incubated with the appropriate secondary antibody (HRP-anti-rabbit IgG or HRP-anti-mouse IgG) for 1 h. qRT-PCR Total RNA was synthesized from 1 g of total RNA using a HISCRIPT 1st strand cDNA synthesis kit (Vazyme, China) the nuclei were stained with 4′-6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, Dinguo, China) the nuclei were stained with 4′-6-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, Dinguo, China) RNA interference Vero cells were grown to 50–60% confluence in 6-well plates. they were transfected with indicated small interfering RNA (siRNA) using polyethylenimine (PEI) 1106 cells were cross-linked with 1% formaldehyde for 10 min at room temperature. PCR was performed with primers specific for HMGB1 gene. cells were plated in 24-well plates at a density of 1105 cells/well. cells were co-transfected with 100ng luciferase reporter plasmids. the supernatant of cell lysate was pre-cleared with protein G for 4h at 4°C. after centrifugation, the supernatant was divided into two parts. one part was incubated with anti-N antibody or anti-HA antibody mixed with protein G. the other part was incubated with anti-rabbit IgG mixed with protein G at 4°C overnight.
